items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Ashley Green, Chesham.

Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in Chesham such as the Vale Road area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.

We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 7th April or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Burn from Southgate and Waterden to Burnham Thorpe
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is still likely today, Monday 29th March, and for the rest of this week. River and groundwater levels remain high and are expected to remain high for the next few weeks. The forecast is for dry conditions today and tomorrow. Take care on riverside footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and levels closely, and will update this message by 10am on Monday 5th April.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom.     
Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom areas are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  
We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of groundwater flooding.   
Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 7th April or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill close to Flamstead.

Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.

We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of groundwater flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 7th April or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels at our Snailwell Borehole are steady but remain high. Consequently there is an increased risk of groundwater flooding. We expect flooding to affect areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street. No rainfall is currently forecast, however there is a risk that the groundwater levels will continue to remain high over the next few weeks. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message is updated weekly due to the slow reaction and will be updated Wednesday 7th April , or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Little Stour, Nailbourne, River Wingham, River Stour

items.message: The Nailbourne & Little Stour have been flowing since mid-January. Levels peaked in February and are now slowly in recession. However, some flooding of low-lying land, gardens and roads is still occurring at various locations including North Elham, Barham, Patrixbourne, Bridge and Littlebourne. Some roads remain closed at fording points. The internal flooding of residential properties is not expected. The Littlebourne Flood Relief Channel is in partial operation and temporary defences operate in Barham. Please avoid driving in floodwater as bow waves from vehicles may cause property flooding. Environment Agency operatives are ensuring the free flow of water. We are monitoring the situation and co-ordinating efforts with local authorities and community leaders. Levels are gradually reducing but this alert will remain in force until more roads are opened to traffic. This message will be updated by Friday 9th April or as the situation changes.

River levels are stable and remain high at Setchey Bridge river gauge. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible. We expect flooding to affect the River Nar from Litcham to South Lynn. Very light rainfall is currently forecast within the next 24 hours.. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Monday 5th April, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels at our observation borehole at Northfield Farm in the Great Shefford area have declined following limited rainfall over the last few weeks. Groundwater levels are still high and close to a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater if we receive heavy rainfall. 

We expect levels to remain high, but continue to slowly fall over the coming week. Water levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message Tuesday (06/04/2021), or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning, and over the next couple of days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide of the Broads river system, due to forecast weather conditions. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning, and over the next couple of days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide of the Broads river system, due to forecast weather conditions. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: The flood alert for North Sea Coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk is now in force. Overtopping waves and spray are expected to affect the Sandsend area tomorrow, Monday 05/04/2021 between 11:00 and 13:45, again on Tuesday 06/04/2021 between 00:00 and 02:30. Please avoid sea-front locations in this area, large waves can be dangerous. You can check flood warnings and alerts on the GOV.UK website. We are monitoring the situation closely and will update this message in 12 hours, or if the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey is now in force. The flood alert has been issued as overtopping waves and spray are expected on high tides at Scarborough. The particular area of concern is Marine Royal Albert Drive, between 14:30 and 15:30 on Monday 05/04/2021. Please stay away from seafront areas. Large waves can be dangerous. Strong winds and large waves are expected to continue during Monday. You can check flood warnings and alerts on the GOV.UK website. We are monitoring the situation closely and will update this message in 12 hours, or if the situation changes.
